content.question:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) In terms of atomic structure, explain why the atomic radius of <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is larger than that of <math alttext="N a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) In terms of atomic structure, explain why the atomic radius of <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is larger than that of <math alttext="N a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) In terms of atomic structure, explain why the first-ionization energy ofÂ <math alttext="K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is less than that of <math alttext="C a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> forms the compound <math alttext="K 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is an ionic compound that is brittle. Identify another element, <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, that is likely to form a brittle, ionic compound with the formula <math alttext="M 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answer in terms of periodic trends.

(d) The compound <math alttext="K 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> also exists. A chemist can determine the mass of <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in a sample of known mass that consists of either pure <math alttext="K 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> or pure <math alttext="K 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. From this information, can the chemist answer the question of which compound is in the sample? Indicate yes or no, and explain.

skill.text: 2.A: Identify a testable scientific question based on an observation, data, or a model.
